titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Gaston Lachaise Collection
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 04:34

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Collection contains correspondence, writings, photographs, scrapbooks, and other materials documenting the life and artistic career of French sculptor Gaston Lachaise. General Correspondence consists chiefly of incoming and outgoing correspondence between Gaston Lachaise and others, including family, friends, artists and writers, art critics and patrons, and cultural institutions. The correspondence features 567 outgoing letters from Lachaise to his wife Isabel Dutaud Nagle Lachaise, dating from 1910 to 1934, and incoming correspondence from New York area artists and cultural figures of the 1920s and 1930s. There are a few pieces of writing by Lachaise and several works by others. Photographs include over 200 black-and-white images of Lachaise, family members, and friends, and of artwork by Lachaise and Pierre-Robert Christophe. Scrapbooks and printed ephemera document publicity and critical reception of Lachaise's work from the 1920s through 1970s and other materials, such as lists of Lachaise's work and the names of private owners, identify his work and document its custodial history. Third-party correspondence can be found between Gaston Lachaise's sister Allys and Lincoln Kirstein and others.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Isabel Lachaise (1949 and 1951), Lincoln Kirstein (1949), and the estate of Allys Lachaise (1968), with additional small gifts and purchases from other sources.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Gaston Lachaise Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Gaston Lachaise Collection. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processing was done on the Gaston Lachaise Collection in 1975 with support from The Lachaise Foundation. During reprocessing of the collection in 2010, the arrangement of correspondence and writings was largely preserved in Series I and II, with two notable exceptions: groups of Allys Lachaise and Lincoln Kirstein correspondence were moved out of the alphabetical run of general correspondence and established as Series VI and VII respectively. In addition, photographs, scrapbooks, and printed ephemera, previously removed from the collection and cataloged separately, were repatriated and can now be found in Series III, IV, and V respectively.
Formerly classed as Za Lachaise, Za L117 +1, Za L117 +2, and Za L117 +G1.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Miscrofilm available for portions of the collection.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The Lachaise Foundation, 10 Federal Street, Boston, Massachusetts, 02110.

bioghist.head: Gaston Lachaise (1882-1935)
bioghist.p: Gaston Lachaise was a French sculptor best known for his female nudes. Born in Paris, Lachaise trained in the decorative arts, and from 1898 to 1904, studied sculpture at the École des Beaux-Arts. He began his artistic career as a designer of Art Nouveau decorative objects for the French jeweler René Lalique. After falling in love with an American woman, Isabel Dutaud Nagle, Lachaise immigrated to the United States in 1906, working first in Boston for H. H. Kitson, an academic sculptor of military monuments, before moving to New York City in 1912.

Biographical information on Gaston Lachaise taken from the Wikipedia entry on Lachaise (accessed 22 December 2010) and the biography of Lachaise by The Lachaise Foundation (accessed 22 December 2010).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Gaston Lachaise collection contains correspondence, writings, photographs, scrapbooks, and other materials documenting the life and artistic career of French sculptor Gaston Lachaise. The General Correspondence in the collection consists chiefly of incoming and outgoing correspondence between Gaston Lachaise and others, including family, friends, artists and writers, art critics and patrons, and cultural institutions. The correspondence features 567 outgoing letters from Lachaise to his wife Isabel Dutaud Nagle Lachaise,dating from 1910 to 1934, and incoming correspondence from New York area artists and cultural figures of the 1920s and 1930s. There are only a few pieces of writing by Lachaise, including a typescript draft of the essay "A Comment on My Sculpture" published in Creative Art in 1928, and several works by others relating to Lachaise. Photographs include over 200 black-and-white images of Lachaise, family members, and friends, and of artwork by Lachaise and French sculptor Pierre-Robert Christophe. Scrapbooks and printed ephemera document publicity and critical reception of Lachaise's work from the 1920s through 1970s and other materials, such as lists of Lachaise's work and the names of private owners, identify his work and document its custodial history. Lastly, third-party correspondence can be found between Gaston Lachaise's sister Allys and Lincoln Kirstein and others.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into seven series: I. General Correspondence, 1906-1957. II. Writings, 1927-1964. III. Photographs, 1867-1944. IV. Scrapbooks, 1918-1945. V. Personal Papers, 1882-1979. VI. Allys Lachaise Correspondence, 1905-1967. VII. Lincoln Kirstein Correspondence Relating to Gaston and Isabel Lachaise, 1933-1961.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I. Correspondence consists chiefly of incoming and outgoing correspondence between Gaston Lachaise and others, including family, friends, artists and writers, art critics and patrons, and cultural institutions. The series features 567 original outgoing letters from Lachaise to his wife Isabel Dutaud Nagle Lachaise, dating from 1910 to 1934, and incoming correspondence from New York area artists and cultural figures of the 1920s and 1930s, including Albert Eugene Gallatin, Marsden Hartley, Lincoln Kirstein, Gorham Munson, Dorothy Norman, Alfred Stieglitz, Carrie Stettheimer, Carl Van Vechten, Edward Warburg, and Marguerite Zorach.
There are a number of letters addressed to Lachaise's wife, most of which follow his death in 1935.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Writings by Gaston Lachaise, Writings by Allys Lachaise, and Writings by Others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II. Writings contains a few pieces of writing by Lachaise, including a typescript draft of the essay "A Comment on My Sculpture" published in Creative Art in 1928, and several works by others relating to Lachaise.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged into thirteen subdivisions: Photographs of the family of Gaston Lachaise; Photographs of Pierre Christophe, his family, and his work; Photographs of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Billet-Petitjean; Photographs of the d'Orgeval family; Photographs of Marie Lachaise; Photographs of Jean Lachaise; Photographs of Allys Lachaise; Photographs of Gaston Lachaise; Photographs of Gaston Lachaise by Carl Van Vechten; Photographs of early work by Gaston Lachaise in the Collection of Mme. Jeane d'Orgeval; Photographs of sculpture by Gaston Lachaise; and Miscellaneous photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III. Photographs contains over 200 black-and-white photographs, including cabinet cards, with images of Gaston Lachaise, family members, and friends, and of his artwork and the artwork of fellow French sculptor Pierre-Robert Christophe. Photographs are identified on the "List of photographs in the Gaston Lachaise Collection" and arranged numerically.
The series includes photographs by Carl Van Vechten.

did.unittitle: "List of photographs in the Gaston Lachaise Collection"

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chonologically by dates of content.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV. Scrapbooks contains exhibition catalogues, letters, clippings, and other ephemera relating to the work of Gaston Lachaise. Scrapbook volumes IV and V contain clippings dating from 1935 onward, following Lachaise's death, and were, possibly along with earlier volumes, compiled by Isabel Dutaud Nagle Lachaise.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V. Personal Papers contains original artwork, lists identifying artwork by Lachaise, the names of private owners of artwork by Lachaise, a small number of personal documents, and printed ephemera documenting publicity for and critical reception of Lachaise's work from the 1920s through 1970s.

did.unittitle: Addresses of owners of Gaston Lachaise's work

List of exhibition items "At Kraushaar Galleries"

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VI. Allys Lachaise Correspondence contains correspondence between Gaston Lachaise's sister Allys and others, as well as additional third-party correspondence between family members and others.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VII. Lincoln Kirstein Correspondence contains correspondence between Lincoln Kirstein and others, including carbons of outgoing letters. Most letters date from the mid 1930s, following Lachaise's death in late 1935, and relate to Kirstein's efforts on behalf of Mrs. Isabel Lachaise and the Lachaise estate.
